pattern.name: IP local
pattern.description:
If it is a local IP address, return 1 else 0.
Note: This pattern only looks at the beginning of the string. So, even "127.nonsense" will be treated as a local IP. To make it worse, we do not respect range: 172.16.0.0 â€“ 172.31.255.255 tightly enough.
Note: Some databases, like PostgreSQL, use a specialized data type for IPs.
Note: This is a specialized version of "prefix" pattern.
pattern.example: Logged traffic from local addresses is likely only for testing purposes. Based on this pattern, we may separate real traffic from dummies.
pattern.author: Jan Motl
pattern.code: SELECT @base , case when (@characterColumn like '10.%' OR @characterColumn like '192.168.%' OR @characterColumn like '172.%') then 1 else 0 end AS @columnName FROM @propagatedTable WHERE @characterColumn is not null
